Karen Rose S. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 18 years old. Karen Rose is single. Karen Rose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Karen Rose has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Karen Rose is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Karen Rose from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

Roger S. lives in the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 26 years old, single and makes a living by running a store where he sells vegetables. He has been in this line of work for more than three years and earns about 7,000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Gulinar

texts.en:
Gulinar is a brave woman who works hard to support her four children, who help her work in the fields while they learn valuable lessons about life and running a household. Gulinar is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers, which she urgently needs to produce a crop that will sell well in the local market. She also plans to use some of the money to buy young cows so that she can produce milk to sell to people who live in her area.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Narzullo

texts.en:
M. Narzullo is a humble man who is the father of four children. He makes a living as a farmer and works hard every day to support his family. His work requires a lot of stamina because he needs to transport animals across long distances while exposed to heat and sun. This can cause illnesses and weaken the body -- but Narzullo continues to work hard, and has come to IMON International for a loan that will allow him to buy young bulls to raise and sell. He would also like to buy potatoes now, while prices are low, so that he can save them to eat later and possibly sell when prices are higher.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which erupted soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have a workable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy young bulls to raise, and potatoes to eat and resell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca S. is from the village of Tangaro, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old and is separated from her spouse. She has eight adult children. Rebecca owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Rebecca plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.name: Vahobjon

texts.en: O. Vahobjon is dedicated to the agriculture and livestock industries, which he serves at his home where he lives with his wife and a son. Vahobjon’s strength in his work is raising livestock and selling potatoes. He has always been dedicated to providing technical assistance for his crops through fumigation and care in order to obtain a good harvest. Now Vahobjon needs to acquire the economic resources to invest in his livestock business such as the purchase of cows to raise and to obtain milk for the family and for commercialization. Also, he wants to purchase potatoes to store for selling when the prices increase. For this reason Vahobjon seeks support from IMON International to obtain a loan that will allow him to succeed in his business. Karomat has been running her own business for more than thirteen years: a grocery store which she attends to herself. She began this business with financial support from her father, the reason for starting the business being to enable her to feed her children. The business has been gradually growing ever since. In order to grow her business Karomat requests a loan of 10,000 Somoni. She is planning to spend the loan on purchasing more stock, thus increasing the range of her goods. She thanks everybody who decides to support her. texts.en:
Henrik H. lives in Agarak town in the Meghri region of Armenia. He has a family consisting of his wire, two children, and his mother.

Henrik works at a local factory as an electrician. To sustain his family he also keeps bees, and honey sales bring his family an additional income.

To increase his income and to reduce the affects of the business’s seasonal nature, Henrik is planning to purchase more bees.

loans.use: To purchase more bees

loans.name: Abdugafar

texts.en:
Abdugafar I. is married and the father of three children. He is a farmer. Educated up to the secondary school level, he had to quit school because he couldn't afford to attend. Abdugafar has a good work ethic. He has wholeheartedly committed himself to agriculture. Thanks to his hard work, he has today become a man known for his determination and serves as an example and reference for other farmers. He has been growing wheat, onions, melons and watermelons for the past twenty years.

Abdugafar is now seeking a loan of 10,500 TJS to buy seeds and fertilizer so as to be prepared for the upcoming season and so produce a good harvest. He can then better meet the needs of his family and improve his working conditions.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich place in history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the farthest reach of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged its already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve their agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have access to reasonable financial services. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim M. Y. (the lady in the photo with her hand raised) is 43 years old and a housewife who stays home and sees to her household responsibilities. She is the mother of six children, all of whom are attending school. She is married to M. Y., a rickshaw driver. The family lives in a small town in Pakistan called Khanewal which is located in Multan, a city famous for its shrines.

Shamim’s husband drives someone else’s rickshaw to whom he pays rent every month. As he is the only breadwinner in his family, his income is unable to meet the financial expenses of his family because the rickshaw rental cuts deeply into his earnings.

Therefore, Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy a rickshaw. By purchasing his own rickshaw he will be able to work fulltime without any worries and will be able to increase his income because rental costs will never cut into his rent. Shamim is very confident that her husband will be able to improve his business by utilizing the loan amount.

Shamim is a regular Asasah client and is her third loan cycle. She has a good credit record and has proved herself responsible in making her repayments on time.

loans.use: To purchase a rickshaw for business use

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad A. M. (PK-10293) is a 24-year-old man living in the town of Melaya - BA..  He is single and does not have any children.  To make a living, Mohamad operates a family member's business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products. He and his parents have meat ball business in the local community.  Mohamad has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 750,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Mohamad joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve  his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Mohamad is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK in the amount of 3,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  Mohamad plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

He dreams of making his business bigger than now and he also hopes that he can have his very own business. He hopes to start up other branches in other places.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in BA. by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.


  


Mohamad A. M. (PK-10293) merupakan 24 tahun pria.  Dia (laki-laki) tinggal di kota Melaya - BA..  Dia (laki-laki) lajang dan tidak memiliki anak.  Untuk membiayai hidup, Mohamad menjalankan usaha milik anggota keluarga.  Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pangan.  Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah membuat & menjual makanan.  Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari menjual produk makanan khusus di tengah masyarakat setempat.  Mohamad sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Mohamad menghasilkan sekitar 750,000 IDR sebulan.


Dalam 2010, Mohamad bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Mohamad telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari MUK.    Dia (laki-laki) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 3,000,000 IDR.  Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli inventaris & modal kerja tambahan.  Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.  Mohamad berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis  untuk tabungan sebagai cadangan bagi keadaan darurat di masa mendatang.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di BA. dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

Pesan untuk Peminjam Kiva: Grup ini memakai model pinjaman komunitas/""community lending"" (biasanya dijuluk Bank Desa/""Village Banking"") yang populer di Asia. Di model ini, sejumlah representatif dari grup akan meminjam uang sejumlah lebih besar untuk seluruh grup (kadang-kadang seluruh desa). Representatif ini akan distribusi dan mengendalikan pinjaman, dan mengkoleksi pembayaran untuk peminjam akhir. Ini adalah praktek umum dan efisien di daerah ini, tapi merumitkan cara lapor untuk Kiva. Tidak serupa pinjaman lain, partner Kiva, MUK, akan menjadi kontak utama dengan tim kepemimpinan grup, yang sebaliknya menjadi kontak dengan peminjam akhir. Demikian, jurnal yang ditulis akan merefleksikan hasilnya tim kepemimpinan, bukannya peminjam-peminjam akhir.

Untuk belajari lebih banyak tentang Village Banking di Wikipedia, mohon kunjungi website ini: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Village_Banking..  "

loans.name: Baatar

texts.en:
Baatar is 48 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in his own house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His eldest son, Enkhtuvshin, 24, is married and lives separately with his wife. He works as a driver in the police department. Baatar’s daughter, Enkhtuul, 22, graduated from college as a chef and is looking for a job at the moment.
Baatar has been running a taxi business for 12 years and has gained valuable experience. On average, he drives 100 kilometers a day, of which 60 kilometers is with passengers. Baatar is one of our reliable customers. He has taken microloans from Kiva partner, Credit Mongol LCC, four times, using them to build a house for his son. This time, he is planning to rebuild his old family house, making a proper wall, roof and extension to the house. The basement was completed last summer. Before the winter he wants to complete the construction work and external decoration of the house. The loan he is asking for will be used to pay for construction materials for the house and some labour costs.

loans.use: To pay for construction materials for the house and some labour costs

loans.name: Huruma Group

texts.fr:
Lukia K. est une commerçante âgée de 47 ans qui habite au Quartier Buyenzi en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes pour femmes depuis 3 ans. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année de l’ecole primaire. Son mari, Eros Kisesa est un mecanicien automobile. Elle arrive au 5e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 6enfants, 4 garçons dont 2 jumeaux et 2 filles  qui sont âgés de  30ans,27ans,24ans,19ans et 14ans pour les 2 jumeaux. Seule l’ainée n’étudie pas, elle est mariée. 
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de pagnes  à vendre dans l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice. Elle espère avoir un grand capital dans l’avenir qui lui permettra de faire un grand business. Elle compte aussi diversifier son business en incluant dans l’avenir, les produits alimentaires car ils procurent un grand bénéfice . Elle reçu le premier capital a travers le crédit de Turame pour démarrer son business. 

 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  Communautaire« Huruma»
texts.en:
Lukia K. is a 47 year old retailer who lives in the the Buyenzi District of Bujumbura. She has been selling women’s “pagnes” (traditional brightly-colored fabric) for 3 years. She studied until the 6th year of primary school. Her husband, Eros Kisesa, is a car mechanic. She is currently in the 5th cycle in the community loan with Turame. She is the mother of 6 children, 4 boys - of which twins - and 2 girls. They are aged 30, 27, 24, 19 and 14 years old for the twins. Only the eldest does not study, she is married. She is requesting a Kiva loan to increase the number of “pagnes“ to sell with the hope of making a big profit. She hopes to have a large capital in the future, which will enable her to run a big business. She also intends to diversify her business by including in the future food products because they provide large profits. She received initial capital through a Turame loan to start her business. She is one of the members of the “Huruma” community group.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the number of “pagnes” to sell in hopes of making a big profit

loans.name: Mekar Sandat Group

texts.en:
Ni Made D. P.  is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Made is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Mekar Sandat (PK-10301).

Ni Made is married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Ni Made owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Made has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 500,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Made joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Made is requesting for the first time a loan from MUK in the amount of 1,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Made plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Made D. P. (0) merupakan 37 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Made adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Mekar Sandat (PK-10301).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Made sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Made menghasilkan sekitar 500,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Made bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Made meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,000,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.name: Nurilya's Group

texts.en:
Nurilya A. is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married. She has a son and three daughters.  The children are at school, except the youngest daughter, who is preschool age (under seven).  Nurilya is a teacher at a school and her husband works at the railway station. Nurilya and her husband also breed cattle; selling milk and some cattle after fattening, they make 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase six lambs in order to resell them after fattening.  In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education.

Saida J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and married.  She has four daughters. The first daughter studies at university, two daughters are at school, and the youngest one is preschool age. Saida works as a cook at a school and her husband works at the railway station. He earns 8000 soms per month. Saida and her husband breed cattle; selling milk and some cattle, they make 5000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for them to improve their living conditions and purchase furniture.  Saida hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase a cow to expand her herd.  In the future she wants to see her daughters get wed.

Zina S., 57, is married.  She has a daughter and a son. The son studies at university and the daughter is at school. Zina works as a teacher at a school and her husband breeds livestock to make money. With money received from the loan, Zina wants to purchase five lambs to raise.  In the future she wants to provide her daughter with a good education and save money to celebrate her son’s wedding. 

Ajarkul  C., 51, is a widow. She is the director of the rural school.  Two years ago Ajarkul started to breed cattle to make money. She sells milk and some farm animals after fattening. In this way she makes 5000 soms per month. Ajarkul is applying for the loan because she wants to purchase a cow to raise. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase lambs

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia H. is from the village of Extension, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 52 years old. Arsenia is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Arsenia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Arsenia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arsenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arsenia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Arsenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita D. R., 37, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She has three children, all of whom are enrolled this school year. By the grace of God, Nenita has managed to pay for her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college--a dream for most Filipino parents like Nenita as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Nenita basically buys general merchandise from wholesalers, then sells it piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products of that sort. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Nenita's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nenita dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Marina

Marina A. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old. Marina is married and has four school-aged children. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kembang Kertas Group

texts.en: Ni Nengah Suharini is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali. She is the group leader of this ten-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Kembang Kertas (PK-10303). Ni Nengah is married and has three school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 300,000 IDR a month. In 2010, Ni Nengah joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her first from MUK. Ni Nengah plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About MUK: The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. ***************************************************** Ni Nengah Suharini (0) merupakan 32 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Ni Nengah adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Kembang Kertas (PK-10303). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Nengah sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Nengah menghasilkan sekitar 300,000 IDR. Dalam 2010, Ni Nengah bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Nengah meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan P., 49, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jose P., an executive secretary, and is the mother of five children, one of whom is already working while one is currently enrolled in college; one is in high school and two are enrolled in the local elementary school. By the grace of God, Susan has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Susan, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Susan operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

Susan is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Susan dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business.

Susan faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products to expand her product inventory

He currently needs 2000 AZN in order to buy construction materials for resale.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has two children, both in school. She also takes care of additional family members. She lives in a home that she owns and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

Regina has a business selling fruits and vegetables and she has been in this business for ten years, working six days per week. She sells her products at the market, both wholesale and retail. The main business challenges for Regina include transportation and perishability. She also generates additional income from rental rooms.

Regina has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sacks of water melons, passion fruits and pineapples.

Regina’s goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow and to earn enough profits to build more rental rooms and educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of melons, passion fruits and pineapples

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en: Bayarmaa B. is 42 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Hentiy province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a ger. Her oldest two children, ages 13 and 14, attend a local secondary school, while her youngest son is in kindergarten. Her husband works on crop land owned by Ulaanbaatar's company as a mechanist, and he has a monthly salary of 300,000 tugriks (MNT). Bayarmaa operates a grocery in her town. She also owns two milk cows and gets 5 liters of milk per day. The small grocery stall she owns is located in a remote ger district of her town. She sells a variety of foodstuffs and consumer products. Bayarmaa started her goods trading business in 2007. Her business is in a good location and there are no competitors in her area. Her daily business income is approximately 15,000-25,000 MNT. She usually purchases her products from a big grocery market in the main city of the province. Once a year, in autumn, she buys a large amount of products from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her business earnings have been used for her family's consumption. For the future, Bayarmaa hopes to locate her small stall near the center of town. She says, "I want to be able to provide for my oldest son's university tuition fees. If my big son gets a good educational background, then he will surely support our entire family. In the future, I also hope to have my own store." She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more supplies and school items for the start of the new academic school year.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies

loans.name: Buyanbaatar

texts.en:
Buyanbaatar, 27 years old, lives with his wife and three children in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. They own a house in a suburb of Darkhan. The eldest daughter is 7 and attends a local school and the two other children go to kindergarten. In 2003, Buyanbaatar bought a car on leasing contract from the bank and started his taxi business. He has been in this business for 7 years and bought a house for his family from his taxi business profit. 

Buyanbaatar’s wife is a disabled woman with a lame leg, but she is a very energetic and enthusiastic businesswoman. She runs a small workshop in which she makes interwoven wool clothes and fabrics. She has six looms and employs four weaver workers. She produces wool products for a local textile factory on subcontract. Her order increases in the winter. 

Buyanbaatar and his wife raise a chicken and ducks in the garden as well. The reason Buyanbaatar is requesting this loan is he wants to build a warm garage for his car and save garage rent money. In wintertime in Mongolia, especially at night, the temperature drops to minus 40 degrees Celsius, which makes starting a car a burden for the drivers. He also wants to buy some wool threads for his wife’s business.

loans.use: To build a warm garage for his car and buy wool threads for his wife's business

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma C. is from the town of Banga. She is 53 years old. Lerma is married and has five grown-up children. To make a living, Lerma plants and harvests rice for sale. Lerma has been farming for over 5 years. She also cooks food that she sells in her neighborhood. She says she needs additional ingredients.

Lerma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers and ingredients for cooking food. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and ingredients for cooking food

loans.name: Genelie

texts.en: Genelie Q. is from the village of Tampason, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Genelie is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Genelie runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells both food and daily-use products and also buys and sells ocean-caught fish. Genelie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Genelie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genelie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Genelie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
This is Rose A., 38. She is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo A., a construction foreman, and is the mother of four elementary-aged children, all of whom are currently enrolled this year. By the grace of God, Rose has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college -- a dream for most Filipino parents like Rose as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Rose operates a food stall while doing sideline work as a manicurist. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only the usual family tradition but is also a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use up cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands (prepared dishes) cost less than raw food. She also generates income from manicure and pedicure services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php16,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy raw ingredients for her food business and other materials needed for her manicure and pedicure services. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rose dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings for her food business and other materials needed for her pedicure and manicure service

loans.name: Beibithan

texts.en:
Beibithan A. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. His oldest two sons attend university and his youngest son attends a local high school. 

Beibithan operates a retail clothing business with the help of his wife. He started a clothes-selling business at a local market named Turlik in 2000, and began to sell winter clothes in a rented stall in Kos Terek, one of main market in his town. His business has grown some levels. He also plants various kinds of fruits and vegetables and sells them to the local market to supplement his earnings.  

He is a hardworking and open-minded person who says, "I want to expand (my) vegetable growing business by increasing (the) land size where I plant (a) variety of vegetables, so that our family can earn extra income from this business." 

Beibithan is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian Tugriks loan to import more clothes from Erlian, a Chinese border city, in order to grow his working capital.

loans.use: To import more clothes

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida M. is from the town of Banga. She is 49 years old, married, and has four adult children. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Zenaida has been involved in her business for over 10 years. She also helps her husband at their farm by keeping the farm free of weeds and pests.

Zenaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products for her store and fertilizers for the farm.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her store and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Buenafe

texts.en:
Buenafe M. is from the village of Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old and married. To make a living, Buenafe owns and operates a  sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Buenafe has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Buenafe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Buenafe is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products for her shop. This loan will be the first taken out by Buenafe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her shop

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline P., 47 years old, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Lino P., a carpenter, and the mother of seven children, one of whom is in college and three of whom are enrolled in high school. The remaining three children stay at home, helping with the chores and running the household while Evangeline and her husband work.

Evangeline operates a rug-making business and does sideline work as a laundry woman. She primarily sells doormats but she also sells rugs, towels, braided quilts, bed sheets, and other crafts. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.  

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional raw materials, such as fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  Evangeline dreams of giving her children a good education through her hard work at her business. 

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups meet each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Ruslan

texts.en:
J. U. Ruslan is an entrepreneurial young man who is engaged in cattle breeding.  In 2007, Ruslan graduated from State Juridical Academy in the capital city Bishkek, but, being a responsible person and grateful son, he returned to his native town, Naryn, to support his elderly parents.  He started his business using initial capital of 10,000 soms (KGS) and bought cattle. With hard work and great effort, Ruslan managed to multiply the number of cattle and today he has four milk cows, two horses and two bull calves. He earns about 2,000 KGS monthly, which allows him to renovate his family’s house. 

Ruslan has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to buy seven calves for fattening and reselling. He is eager to broaden his business because he plans to marry his girlfriend. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Byambajav

texts.en:
Byambajav D. is 25 years old and lives with his six brother and sisters in Hovd province, western Mongolia. He and his brothers and sisters live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He has four younger sisters and brothers – two attend a university and the other two attend a local secondary school. His elder two sisters work as cooks at Tsomorlik restaurant.
Byambajav operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi in 2007 and has gained much experience. In the future, he plans to study in higher education and have a good permanent job after majoring in a specific field. He says, "I am saving money to study for a higher education degree. All I want is to train myself in a specific occupation." He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase machinery parts for his car and concrete blocks.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts for his car

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is Marivic O., 43, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Flaviano O., a painter/maintenance man, and is the mother of three children. One of her children is already working while one is currently enrolled in college and the other is still in high school. By the grace of God, Marivic has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Marivic, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Marivic is currently concentrating on her buying and selling business. She buys general merchandise from wholesalers and sells it piecemeal to make a little profit. Her products range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, food supplements and other products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Marivic is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP. She will be using the loan to expand her product inventory by purchasing more products and a greater variety. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Marivic dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine C. is from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 24 years old and single. To make a living, Christine owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for sale. Christine has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Christine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Damis

texts.en:
Damis H. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in the Hentiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in his relative's yard. His three sons attend a local secondary school and his wife works in a cafe as an assistant cook, earning a monthly salary of 85,000 MNT.
Damis operates a taxi service in his town. He began his taxi business in 2008 and has gained a lot of experience since then. His business earnings are the main source of his family's income. His daily business income is around 15,000 to 20,000 MNT. Damis is a very peaceful and helpful person who plans to repair his car before the winter season. "I work hard to support my family. I want to repair my car and transport my customers in a nice and comfortable car," he says. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to buy spare parts for his car, which cost 380,000 MNT, and to purchase clothes for his children, which cost 120,000 MNT.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his car

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Margaret has had a restaurant business for over ten years and she works six days every week. Margaret works from home and sells to all categories of people on retail basis.    

Margaret has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bananas, rice, charcoal, crates of soda and beer, beef and chicken. Margaret's main business challenges are seasonality and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked hotel and build her own business premises. Margaret lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bananas, rice, beef, crates of beer, soda and chicken

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
This is Alicia A., 52, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Abraham, a mason, and is the mother of a high-school-aged young adult. By the grace of God, Alicia has managed to support her child’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child to college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Alicia, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Alicia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Alicia earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy more products, such as groceries, toiletries and beverages, to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Alicia hopes that her business will be successful someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory by purchasing groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon G. is from the town of Banga. She is married. To make a living, Corazon owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Corazon has been involved in her business for over six years.
Corazon joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Chuchie

texts.en:
This is Chuchie S., a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Freddie S., a driver, and is the mother of a young adult currently enrolled in college and a youngster enjoying his high school days. By the grace of God, Chuchie has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Chuchie, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Chuchie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Chuchie earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 250 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Chuchie is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP. She will be using the loan to buy more products, such as groceries, toiletries and beverages, to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Chuchie dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory by purchasing groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mamadou Sangaré est un homme marié de 30 ans et sans enfant qui vit avec sa femme à Bougouni dans le quartier Torakabougou.
Après l’école coranique, il est resté longtemps sans aucun  emploi.
C’est ainsi qu’après mûre réflexion, il décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami le commerce notamment l’achat et la vente des chaussures et vêtements (prêts à porter : chemises, pantalons etc).
Après avoir eu un petit fonds de roulement, il décide de mener seul ses activités.
Avec 6 années d’expériences, il maîtrise  bien son activité.
Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il décide d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter des  paires de vêtements.
Il s’approvisionne à Lomé et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Ses clients sont composés d’hommes et femmes. 
Les fêtes religieuses et les grandes cérémonies (baptême, mariages) sont les périodes où les ventes de ses articles sont intenses.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA   Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou Sangaré, 30 years old, is married without children. He lives with his wife in Bougouni in the Torakabougou district. After finishing Quranic school, he remained without work for a long time. And thus, following some pointed reflection, he decided to learn the line of business a friend of his was in: retailing shoes and clothing (ready-to-wear: shirts, trousers etc). Once he had a small starting capital ready, he launched an independent business. Now, with six years of experience, he knows his trade well. In order to boost his business, he decided to participate in the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. With this loan he plans to purchase some outfit sets. He stocks up in Lomé and in Bamako (the capital of Mal). His customer base is composed of both men and women. His sales go up during religious holidays and on big festive occasions (such as baptisms and weddings). With this loan, he plans to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs. In the future, he anticipates expanding his store.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing

loans.name: Lorence

texts.en:
This is Lorence L., 47, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Ireneo L., an auto electrician, and is the mother of an elementary-aged child. By the grace of God, Lorence has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Lorence, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Lorence operates a meat shop where she also sells native milkfish delicacies such as boneless ones, meat-filled ones, and other products of the like. For her meat shop, she buys live pigs from hog-raisers. The pigs are then slaughtered and sold to the immediate community. She has many customers who buy the cut meat and then sell it on their respective market stalls. There are many customers who prefer Lorence’s products since they are assured of their freshness and cleanliness. It is also a little cheaper to buy meat from an independent meat shop than the ones in the market that sometimes use the services of professional slaughterhouses for their meat. The cost of slaughter is added to the final price of the cut meat, and passed along to the customers. Thus, Lorence has many customers who regularly anticipate her meat and processed milkfish. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 600 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Lorence is requesting a loan of 22,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy live pigs to be slaughtered and sold every day. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Lorence dreams of being able to give her child a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her own market stall someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy live pigs, milkfish in bulk and ingredients for processing

loans.name: Nana

texts.fr:
Madame Nana Sidibé est une femme mariée de 43 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit  dans une famille polygame avec son époux, ses enfants et ses co-épouses dans le quartier Médine de Bougouni. 
Suite à la pauvreté de ses parents, elle décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des habits etc. Elle a appris cette activité à travers une sœur.
Avec une expérience de plus de 8 ans elle maîtrise son activité.
Pour obtenir un fonds de roulement consistant, elle décida d’intégrer une association de crédit solidaire de dans son quartier. Après 2 prêts solidaires, elle est passée au prêt individuel.Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter,  des habits au Burkina et effectuera sa vente au marché de Bougouni  dans sa boutique. La plus part de sa clientèle est composée essentiellement des femmes.
Elle  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA.
Avec se bénéfice elle compte payer les intérêts du prêt et  agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nana Sidibé, 43 years old, is married and the mother of three children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her children and her husband’s other wives in the Médine district of Bougoni. Since her parents had no resources, she decided to earn a living by selling clothing. She has learned this line of business from her sister. Now, with over eight years of experience, she excels at what she does. In order to maintain a constant level of working capital, she decided to join the solidarity credit association in her district. After two solidarity loans, she moved on to an individual loan. All previous loans have been duly repaid. With this loan she plans to purchase outfits at Burkina Faso in order to resell them at her store at the Bougouni market. For the most part, her customers are women. She hopes to achieve a monthly income of 50,000 West African Francs, which she plans to use for repaying the interest on her loan and for growing her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
This is Lucy C., 38, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Andres C., a company driver, and is the mother of three children. One of her children is already working while one is enrolled in high school and the youngest is still in elementary school. At this time, Lucy is working hard to send her two younger children all the way through college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Lucy, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Lucy operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Lucy earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale price and selling at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 9,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Lucy dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
This is Beatriz C., 55, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo C., a driver, and is the mother of a young adult enrolled in college and an elementary-aged youngster. By the grace of God, Beatriz has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Beatriz, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Beatriz operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Beatriz earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, Beatriz is requesting a loan of 39,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Beatriz dreams of having franchises and branches of her store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory by purchasing groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Davaadulam

texts.en:
Davaadulam G. is a single mother who lives with her parents and five-year-old son in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. They all live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home, in a rented yard. Davaadulam's parents are retired and her son, Uuganbayar, is in kindergarten.
Davaadulam operates a cosmetics trading business from a rented stall at Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's largest market. She started her business in 2008 after graduating from Mongolian National University as a lawyer. In April 2010, Davaadulam also began to rent a stall at Narantuul to sell electrical home products. Her business earnings have enabled her to build a grocery store in her yard. She is working very hard to finish her grocery shop construction. She says, "I hope that if I start to operate my grocery shop, which is under construction now, then I can earn more business profits". She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to build the grocery shop.

loans.use: To build a grocery shop

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita T., 39, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Frederick, and is the mother of two children, both of whom are in high school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both her children all the way through college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Anita, who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.
Anita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Anita earns an income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and local community members. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 19,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Anita dreams of having new businesses in the future. She also prays for good health for her and her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory by purchasing groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Monsieur Daouda Sidibé est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougouni, dans le quartier Faraba (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son père.
Depuis  maintenant 10 ans, il mène les activités de fabrication de marmites, de louches etc. Il maîtise bien son activité et est très sollicité à Bougouni et dans les villages environnants.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client de l’institution, il décide de collaborer avec cette dernière (avec qui il est à  sa première expérience) pour acheter, une grande quantité d’aluminum et 15 sacs de charbon de bois.
Il s’approvisionne en aluminuim à Bougouni et quelques fois à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et quant au charbon de bois, exclusivement à Bougouni auprès des paysans producteurs.                                                                                                                                                                              La vente de sa production se fait au marché de Bougouni et dans les villages anvironnants, à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son entreprise.
Monsieur Daouda Sidibé est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougouni, dans le quartier Faraba (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son père.
Depuis  maintenant 10 ans, il mène les activités de fabrication de marmites, de louches etc. Il maîtrise bien son activité et est très sollicité à Bougouni et dans les villages environnants.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client de l’institution, il décide de collaborer avec cette dernière (avec qui il est à  sa première expérience) pour acheter, une grande quantité d'aluminium et 15 sacs de charbon de bois.
Il s’approvisionne en aluminium à Bougouni et quelques fois à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et quant au charbon de bois, exclusivement à Bougouni auprès des paysans producteurs.                                                                                                  La vente de sa production se fait au marché de Bougouni et dans les villages environants, à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Daouda Sidibé is 41 years old, married and the father of three children. He lives with his wife and children in a traditional extended family in the Faraba borough of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He did not attend modern schools, but from an early age engaged in revenue-generating activities alongside his father. For ten years his activity has been to manufacture pots and ladles, etc. He masters well this activity and is quite sought after in Bougouni and surrounding villages. He learned of Soro Yiriwaso through another client of the institution, and decided to collaborate with the institution (this being his first experience) in buying a large quantity of aluminum and 15 bags of charcoal. He gets his aluminum supplies in Bougouni and sometimes from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). As for the charcoal, he gets it exclusively from local producers in Bougouni. He sells his wares at the Bougouni market and in the surrounding villages, to mainly women customers. He hopes to attain monthly earnings of 40,000 FCFA he will use to expand his business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy aluminum

loans.name: Fatimata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatimata Touré est une femme mariée de 44 ans et mère de 1 enfant. Elle vit chez ses parents dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative du Mali)
Madame Fatimata a vite abandonné (à cause des raisons sociales) l’école pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus.
Pour subvenir à ses propres dépenses, à celles de sa famille tout en aidant son époux, elle décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des bazins, des chaussures, des articles de fête et vêtements pour enfants.
Avec une expérience de plus de 6 ans elle maitrise  cette activité qu’elle a appris auprès d’une de ses amie.
 Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé et à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) auprès des grossistes.
Elle a intégré le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour  renforcer son fonds de commerce en vu d’acheter des bazins et vêtements pour enfants qui seront vendus aux marché de Bougouni dans sa boutique.
Elle est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
 Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatimata Touré is 44 years old, married and the mother of one child. She lives in her parents’ home in the North Hérémakono borough of Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali). For social reasons, Mrs. Fatimata soon left school to engage in revenue-generating activities. To meet her needs, those of her family as well as assisting her husband, she decided to conduct several activities, in particular the retail commerce of bazin (damask fabric), shoes, party supplies and children’s’ clothing. With more than six years’ experience, she now masters this activity she learned from a friend. She resupplies from wholesalers in Lomé and in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). She joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan programme to reinforce her working capital in view of buying bazin fabric and children’s clothing, to be sold in her shop at the Bougouni market. This is her first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. She hopes this loan will enable her to reach monthly earnings of 65,000 FCFA.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bazin fabric and children's clothing

loans.name: Dalal

texts.en:
