Dalal is a young housewife and mother from Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza Strip. Dalal has two daughters, and her husband, Hazem, is a Ministry of health employee. Dalal and Hazem own a womens' clothing store in Jabalia refugee camp. Hazem works in the store and she helps him sometimes.

Dalal and Hazem opened the store two years ago, and the store is slowly prospering. Dalal came to FATEN to take a $1,000 loan in order to start fixing and decorating the store as it needs shelves and stands. Dalal also wants to buy extra clothing inventory.

Dalal's husband, Hazem, appears in the picture as she doesn't like to be photographed.

loans.use: To purchase store decorations

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion C., aged 50, has three children – one in college, one in high school, and one in elementary school. She works hard each day to cover her daily costs and help send her children to school. For the past ten years, Asuncion has run her own sari-sari store (general store) and barbeque, and has used her earnings to support her family.
Asuncion has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to help restock her sari-sari store with groceries, soft drinks, and toiletries. She hopes that the additional inventory will attract new customers and help grow her business.
Asuncion has been a member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), since 2005 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship* meetings. She hopes that her business will continue to expand and that some day she will be able to afford her own vehicle and provide additional money for her children's education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Guljamish

texts.en:
Guljamish I. is a 65-year-old widow who lives with her three daughters in a house in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. Her oldest and youngest  daughters are currently unemployed while her middle daughter helps in his mother's business. Guljamish's husband passed away ten years ago.
Guljamish operates a sewing business in her town producing traditional clothes and home products. She worked in the garment industry from 1985 to 1995, then started her own business in a rented workplace in 1996. Since then she has built a stable operation. She pays rent of 30,000 MNT per month. Over the many years of operating her business, her earnings have enabled her to pay tuition fees for her three daughters. Now all her daughters are married and live separately from their mother. 
Guljamish usually makes a variety of home felt items and traditional ornaments. During the summer months, demand for her products is increased so she needs to purchase more materials in order to meet customer demand. Guljamish is a very hardworking and open-minded person. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to import more fabrics and materials from Taikeshken state, China.

loans.use: To import more fabrics and materials for her business

loans.name: Hamadoun Amadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Hamadoun Amadou M. est un homme marié de 29 et sans enfant. Il vit chez lui même à Bougouni dans le quartier Hérémakono Centre.
Après les études secondaires où il obtient le diplôme de Technicien en Agro-Pastoral, il est resté pendant des années sans emploi. 
C’est ainsi qu’il décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus. Pendant des années, il assista un de ses ami, vendeur de boutique au  grand marché de Bougouni pour apprendre cette activité.
Avec une expérience de 2 ans, il maîtrise son activité.
Afin de renforcer son activité, il décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son  premier prêt,  pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente à une clientèle  composée de la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 62.500 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Hamadoun Amadou M. is 29 years old, married without children. He lives in his own home in the Central Hérémakono borough of Bougouni. Following secondary schooling where he obtained a degree in pastoral agriculture, he remained unemployed for several years. As a result he decided to engage in revenue-generating activities. For years he assisted one of his friends, a shop vendor in Bougouni’s main market, to learn the business. With two years’ experience, he now masters this activity. To strengthen his business activity, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso for a first loan to buy various items for his shop. He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Bamoko and sells to the local population. With this loan he hopes to attain monthly earnings of 62,500 FCFA. He is considering using his earnings to expand his shop.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items for shop

loans.name: Ibréhima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibréhima Sidibé est un homme marié de 37 ans et père de 5 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son père à Bougouni dans le quartier Dialanicoro.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus, avec l’apprentissage d’un métier.
Depuis plus de17 ans il mène l’activité de fabrication de marmites. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son oncle. Monsieur Ibréhima a une  solide maîtrise son activité.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, il décide de solliciter un deuxième prêt pour acheter, 15 tas d'aluminium et 9 sacs de charbons  de bois.                                                                                                                                                                 Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni. La vente de sa production se fait au marché Bougouni et dans les marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants.  Sa clientèle est essentiellement  constituée de femmes
Monsieur Ibréhima Sidibé compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50.000 FCFA.
Avec ses bénéfices il envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibréhima Sidibé is 37 years old, married and the father of five chiildren. He lives with his wife and children in his father’s home, in the Dialanicoro borough of Bougouni. He did not attend modern schools, and from an early age engaged in revenue-generating activities, by learning a trade. For over 17 years his business activity has been to manufacture cooking pots. He learned the activity from his uncle, and has developed a solid mastery at his trade. After fully reimbursing a first loan, he decided to request a second loan to buy 15 piles of aluminium and 9 bags of charcoal. He resupplies in Bougouni and sells his wares at the Bougouni market and at the weekly markets of villages in the vicinity. His customers are for the most part women. Mr. Ibréhima Sidibé hopes to attain monthly earnings of 50,000 FCFA. He envisions using his earnings to expand his business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy aluminum

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka Traoré est un homme marié de 31 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son oncle à Bougouni dans le quartier Torakabougou.
Ayant vite abandonné l’école dès son jeune âge, il décida d’apprendre le métier de tailleur auprès de son oncle.
Il a 10 années d’expérience dans ce domaine qu’il maîtrise bien. En plus de ses prestations de couture, il vend actuellement les matériels que les tailleurs et couturiers utilisent fréquemment.
Pour renforcer ses activités, il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à sa première expérience.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, des tissus, boutons, chaînes, fil, aiguilles etc pour les revendre à une clientèle composée de tailleurs et  couturiers.
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako (Capitale de république du Mali).
Les fêtes religieuses constituent les moments où il y a plus de ventes. 
Il  compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de  40 500 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il compte améliorer son atelier afin d’attirer les clients, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille et ouvrir un autre atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Traoré is 31 years old, married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children in his uncle’s home in the Torakabougou borough of Bougouni. Having stopped going to school at an early age, he decided to learn the tailoring trade from his uncle. He now has ten years’ experience in this activity which he masters well. In addition to his tailoring activity, he also sells material often used by tailors and dressmakers. To strengthen his business he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan programme where this will be his first experience. With the loan he wants to buy fabric, buttons, chains, thread, needles, etc., for resale to a customer base of tailors and dressmakers. He gets his supplies from Bougouni and Bamoko (capital of the Republic of Mali). Religious festivities are the time when sales are at their peak. He is counting on monthly earnings of 40,500 FCFA. With his earnings he will make improvements to his workshop to attract customers, contribute towards family expenses and open another workshop.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sewing material

loans.name: Adiara

texts.fr:
Madame Adiara Sangaré est une femme mariée de 29 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni. 
Ayant vite abandonnée l’école dès à son jeune âge, elle s’initia aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et la vente des pagnes et chaussures. Avec plus de 6 ans d’expérience, elle maîtrise son activité, qu’elle a appris auprès de sa mère. 
C’est dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, qu’elle décide de collaborer  avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des pagnes et  des chaussures. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali)
Elle est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elle mène cette activité dans les différents quartiers de Bougouni et  au  grand marché les jours des foires. 
Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 38 000FCFA. 
Avec ce bénéfice elle envisage agrandir son entreprise afin de devenir un jour grossiste.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiara Sangaré, 29 years old, is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and children in the Hérémakono North district of Bougoni. Having left school at an early age, she started working to earn an income, in particular by selling “pagnes” [traditional colorful fabric] and shoes. Now, with over 6 years of experience, she excels in this line of business she has learned from her mother. Looking for additional financial resources, she decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso in order to purchase “pagnes” cloth and shoes. She stocks up in Bamako (the capital of Mali). This is her first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. She sells her wares in different districts of Bougnoui and at the big market on market days. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 38,000 West African Francs. Thanks to this income, she envisages expanding her business and eventually becoming a wholesaler.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing shoes and traditional "pagnes" fabrics

loans.name: Bourama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bourama Konaté est un homme marié de 29 ans et père d’un enfant qui vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans le quartier Massablacoura de Bougouni.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus telle la vente des habits. Cette activité ne lui est pas réussi, alors il décida de suivre son oncle pour apprendre la vente d’articles divers dans une boutique.
 Avec une expérience de plus 2 ans, Monsieur Bourama Konaté maîtrise son activité.
Pour obtenir un fonds de roulement consistant, il décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique. Il est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40.000FCFA Avec ce bénéfice il ambitionne  agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Bourama Konaté is a 29 year-old married man. He lives with his wife and child in the Massablacoura neighborhood of Bougouni. Not having attended a modern school, at a young age he embarked on activities that would generate an income, such as selling clothing. That business was not successful for him. Then, he decided to observe his uncle to learn about selling grocery items in a store. After more than two years of experience, Mr. Bourama Konaté has mastered his business. In order to obtain a consistent working capital, he decided to affiliate with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program to buy a variety of grocery items for his store. This is his first loan with Soro Yiriwaso. He gets his supplies in Bamako (capital of the republic of Mali) from wholesalers. His customers come from the local population. He expects to make a monthly profit of 40,000 CFA with this loan. He wants to use the loan to expand his store.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of items for his store

loans.name: Germina

texts.en:
Germina N. lives in the Mengo Kisenyi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has seven children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her grandchildren).
Germina has a business selling passion fruits. She has been in this business for less than a year, and she works six days a week. Germina sells her products at the market on a retail basis. She has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy sacks of passion fruits. She also generates additional income through her rental rooms.
The main business challenges for Germina are seasonality and thieves. Her goal and aspiration for the business is to sell wholesale only. Germina lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding her family and medication.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of passion fruits

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yacouba Dembélé est un marié de 31 ans et père de 3 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son père, dans le quartier Dougounina  de Bougouni.
Monsieur Yacouba Dembélé a vite abandonné l’école au profit des activités génératrices de revenus.
Pendant des années  menait l’activité d’achat et de vente des céréales au marché de Bougouni et cela sans réussite.
C’est ainsi qu’il décida d’apprendre un métier et décide de faire de la menuiserie bois. Il a appris cette activité  auprès de son grand frère.
Avec plus de 10 années d’expérience, il maitrise son activité
Dans le souci d’honorer ses commandes, il décide d’intégrer  Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui il est à sa première expérience.
Il compte acheter des bois,  des pointes, des  colles et autres petits matériels de la menuiserie bois. Il s’approvisionne essentiellement à Bougouni.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice, il envisage agrandir son entreprise et payer les intérêt du prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Yacouba Dembélé is a 31-year-old married man and father to three children. He and his family live with his father in the neighborhood of Dougounina, in Bougouni. Mr. Dembélé dropped out of school early on to earn a living. He spent several years buying and selling cereals at the Bougouni market, without success. He then decided to learn a trade, opting for woodwork. He learned this activity from his older brother and now, with over 10 years of experience, he has a good command of his trade. In order to meet customer demand, he has decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. This is his first experience with the micro-finance institution. He plans to buy wood, nails, glue and other small woodwork equipment. He gets his supplies primarily in Bougouni. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA, which he plans to use to expand his business and pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wood, nails, glue, etc.

loans.name: Venera

texts.en:
Venera S. is a resident of Balykchi, a nice city in the Isykul region. Venera is 37 years old, married, and has two sons and a daughter. Her sons are at school and her daughter is not yet in school. In order to make money, Venera sells apricots and apples grown in her garden. She also sells about 20 liters of milk per day (earning 10 TJS per liter). Venera's husband earns money to cover family expenses by working in construction.
Venera also breeds livestock. She had 40 farm animals, but sold all of them to finish building her house. With her loan, she wants to purchase livestock for breeding. Her dream for the future is to provide her children with a good education.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Adama Sidibé est un homme marié de 36 ans et père de 6 enfants qui  vit avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Bougouni dans le quartier Dougounina.
Monsieur Adama Sidibé n’a pas  fréquenté l’école moderne mais plutôt l’école coranique. Afin de subvenir à ses besoins il utilisait une charrette pour transporter les marchandises des commerçants de Bougouni. C’est ainsi qu’après une longue réflexion, il décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami le commerce d’achat et de vente des articles de fêtes,  des chaussures et d’habits.
Après quelques années d’économie et l’aide de certaines connaissances  il décide d’ouvrir une boutique des prêt à porter. Avec 6 années d’expériences, il maîtrise son activité.
Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il décide d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso qu’il a connu à travers un ami.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter des chaussures, chemises et pantalons.
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Sa  clientèle est composée d’hommes et femmes. Les fêtes religieuse et les grandes cérémonies (baptême, mariages) sont les périodes où les ventes  sont les plus élevées.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de  50 000 FCFA.
Dans les années à venir  Adama Sidibé  ambitionne agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama Sidibé is a 36 year-old married man and the father of 6 children. He lives with his two wives and their chldren in the Dougounina neighborhood of Bougouni. Mr. Sidibé did not attend a modern school but rather a Koranic school. In order to support himself, he used a cart to transport the merchandise of Bougouni shopkeepers. After reflecting at length, he decided to learn about the business of buying and selling festival items, shoes and clothing, from his friend. After saving for a few years and with the help of some friends, he decided to open a ready-to-wear shop. After 6 years of experience, he has mastered his business. Within the framework of expanding his business, he decided to affiliate with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program which he knew about from a friend. He plans to buy shoes, shirt and pants with this loan. He gets his supplies in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). His clientele is made up of men and women. Religious holidays and important ceremonies (baptism, marriages) are the periods when his sales are the highest. He expects to make a monthly profit of 50,000 CFA with this loan. Mr. Sidibé hopes to expand his shop in the future.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes, shirts and pants

loans.name: Marat

texts.en:
Marat H. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Marat's oldest daughter attends a local elementary school and  his younger daughters are in kindergarten. 

Marat currently operates a transportation service in his town. He first went into business in 2000 by transporting and delivering cargo using his own truck. He usually delivers various kind of loads both from Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city and Tashkent, China's border city. He also transports coals and fire wood and sells them in his town to supplement his earnings. His business has not stabilized yet because of the high price of truck fuel. His earnings have enabled him to build a new 2 room house for his family. Marat is very hardworking and honest person. For the future, he says, "I am trying hard to earn enough money to build a  big house for my family." 

He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase wheels for his truck and some coal and firewood from the countryside to resell.

loans.use: To purchase wheels for his truck

loans.name: Jequicene

texts.pt:
Jequicene C. nasceu na Provincia de Inhambane Sul de Moçambique tem 50 anos de idade, casado e pai de 12 filhos de idade idades entre 7 a 28 anos de idade. Fez a 5ª classe não deu continuidade devido a distância que o separava da casa a Escola que lecionava o outro nivel. Vive na casa propria com sua familia. Responsabiliza se pelos seus pais que vivem com ele em sua casa.  
Sai de Inhambane para Namaacha a procura de emprego, após 12 anos de trabalho como guarda começa a praticar negócio de venda de potes consegue construir duas casas uma ves que tem duas Esposas e ainda comprar uma viatura para lhe facilitar no seu trabalho. Agora para além da venda de potes, faz transporte de passageiros na sua zona e tem um rendimento diario de 200.00mtn. também faz criação de frangos onde gasta 50,000.00mtn para criar 800 pintos, tem ganho um rendimento de 15,000.00mt que aplica nas dispesas da sua casa e poupa cerca de 2.000.00 a 3.000.00mt por mês na sua bancaria. 

Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Jequicene na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 22.000mt com o qual pretende comprar pintos, raçoes e vitaminas para aumentar quantidade da sua criação. Os dois primeiros de (18.000.00mt e 22.000.00mt) foi para a mesma finalidade, esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para construir um estabelecimento para venda de potes.
texts.en:
Jequicene was born in the Inhambane province, South of Mozambique. He is 50 years old, married and the father of 12 children between 7 and 28 years of age. He went to school until 5th grade and didn't continue due to the distance between his home and the middle school. He lives in his own house with his family and supports his parents who live with him. He left Inhambane to Namaacha looking for a job. After 12 years working as a guard he started a business selling pots. He managed to build two houses given that he has two wives and to buy a car to help him in his job. Currently, besides selling pots he also transports people in his area making 200.00 meticais per day. He also raises chickens and spends 50,000 meticais to raise 800 chicks. He has an income of 15,000 meticais which is applied towards household expenses. He saves around 2,000 to 3,000 meticais in his bank account. This is Jequicene's third loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. It is for 22,000 meticais and will be used to purchase chicks, feed and vitamins to increase his flock. The two first loans (for 18,000 and 22,000 meticais) were used for the same goal. He is confident he will pay the loan back ahead of schedule and request another loan to build a shop to sell pots.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicks, feed and vitamins

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag is 35 years old and lives with her husband, son and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They own a plot of land and a small house in the suburb of Ulaanbaatar. Two children attend a local secondary school. Tungalag and her husband have run a building material retail business since 2006. Once a month she or her husband travel to Ereen, the Chinese city on Mongolian border, and buy necessary building materials to resell in Ulaanbaatar city for a profit. In the off building season (winter time), she just orders the essential materials from her sister to bring from China. They also buy plumbing materials, 2 to 3 times a week, from a wholesale point and resell them. They rent a stall in Hermes Center, one of the biggest and most crowded building material retail and wholesale markets in Ulaanbaatar. 

Tungalag future plan is to extend her business as a wholesaler and to build a bigger house for her family. The reason she is asking for this loan is to increase her working capital, which will bring more profit for the business and family.

loans.use: To increase her working capital and buy more inventory for her stall

loans.name: Ozbekov

texts.en:
Ozbekov A. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in Isykul region.  A. is 45 years old and he is married. He has two sons, both of them are at school.  In order to earn some money A. purchased cement in the factory and then sold it at a higher price near the home.  In this way he earned 10000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for him to save money and purchase cattle.  He breeds cattle and then resells them after fattening at the higher price. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase two bulls for breeding.  In the future he wants to rent a place and start selling building materials.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase bulls

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en: Gertrude N. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (three relatives).   Gertrude has a business selling fish.  She has been in this business for 8 years, and she works 1 day out of every week. Gertrude sells her products at the market at wholesale prices.   Gertrude has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of fish.   She also generates additional income by selling water and passion fruit juice from her refrigerator. The main business challenge(s) for Gertrude are thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are enhancing the development of her life style.   Gertrude lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, mediation and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish

loans.name: Oyunsuren

texts.en:
Oyunsuren D. lives with her mother, husband and two children in an apartment in the Chigeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband runs a taxi service to support his family. Her two children attend a secondary school. Oyunsuren is a salesperson and started her business by selling shoes and clothes in 2007 in the Bumbugur market, one of the main markes in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. However, her business had not proven too successful so she decided to start trading a grocery products like floor, rice and sugar in the Bars Market, Ulaanbaatar's biggest grocery market, in April, 2010. 

Oyunsuren is a very hardworking and  intelligent person. She is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to grow her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more floor, rice and suger

loans.name: Bdec Hec Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you the teachers of the B.D.E.C Home Economics school in Makeni. B.D.E.C Home Economics was established in 1978 to help fight gender disparity. The school is staffed with thirteen teachers and children between the classes of five and six from all primary schools in Makeni attend the school on alternate days of the week. 

These hardworking and dedicated teachers have come to SMT, to seek a loan of SLL 3,000,000. This is not the first SMT loan that these teachers have benefited from: previous loans have made a lot of improvements in the lives of these borrowers. 

Helen F. (pictured second from the right) is the headmistresses and leader of this group of teachers. She is age forty-nine and has been in the teaching profession for twenty-four years now. She is married to a lecturer and they have four children, all of whom are in college. With the help of this loan, Helen and her colleague teachers will be able to pay school and college fees for their children.

Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.

loans.use: To pay college fees for her children

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his university education fees

loans.name: Raikan

texts.en:
Raikan K. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in the Isykul region.  She is 45 years old, married, and she has a son who is sixteen and studies at school.  She is a farmer. She cultivates different fruits and vegetables. In order to make money she sells some part of the harvest. Her husband works as a private driver.  

Raikan wants to start breeding cattle in order to resell them after fattening. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two bulls for breeding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two bulls for breeding

loans.name: Aldabergen

texts.en:
Aldabergen D. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children, aged 5 and 3, both attend a local kindergarten. His wife is currently working for the elementary school as a teacher. 

He operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi in 1998 and has built a stable operation. With his good moral character, he has increased his customer base. He usually transports people between neighboring sub-provinces. His earnings have enabled him to build a new house for his family. 

For the future, Aldabergen hopes to expand his business. He is a very pleasant and hardworking person and says, "I am saving money for my children's future education." 

He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to buy three tons of coal, which costs 180,000 MNT, and one truckload of grass in preparation for the winter.

loans.use: To buy three tons of coal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 19-year-old single man living with his parents and 2 siblings. He is from Lebanon.  Despite his young age, he started working as a furniture painter 5 years ago.  In parallel, he is attending university. 

He works hard to manage his time between his business and his education. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to pay for his university fees. He is studying tourism and is in his second year of school.

In the future, he is planning to work in a travel agency or in an airline company because he likes to travel a lot.

loans.use: To pay for his university education fees

loans.name: Kanymbubu

texts.en:
Kanymbubu S. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in the Isykul region. Kanymbubu is 45 years old and she is married.  Her husband is a pensioner. She has raised two sons and two daughters. The sons are married and live separately with their families and the daughters work in Russia. 

In order to make money, Kanymbubu sells milk every day. She also sells apricots raised in her own garden. Her husband breeds livestock and sells some farm animals each month. With money received from the loan, Kanymbubu wants to purchase five sheep and three goats in order to increase the number of livestock. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina M. lives in the lugala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She has no additional family members.  She has a business of operating a bar.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. She sells her products from home at retail prices. The main business challenges for Madina include seasonality. 

Madina has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy crates of beer and soda.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked bar.  

She decided to join MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by acquiring additional capital.  Madina lives in a home that she rents and has access to electricity and no piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: T o buy more crates of beer and soda

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her courses at the university

loans.name: Beisenbek

texts.en:
Beisenbek E. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest two children attend a local secondary school while his two younger children are in kindergarten. 

His wife is currently unemployed. Beisenbek operates a goods transportation business in his town.  He started his business in 2003 by transporting coal and firewood between sub-provinces. He transports coal and firewood using his own truck with trailer and sells it in local markets. His truck can transport a load of up to 15 tons, which allows him to make 6-8 trips during the winter season and 8-10 trips in the summer. His business earnings are the only source of his family's income. 

He is a very modest and quiet person. For the future, Beisenbek hopes to continue making progress with his business and says, "All I want is to build a house for my family." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wheels for his truck and to grow his working capital.

loans.use: To purchase wheels for his truck

loans.name: Celina

texts.pt:
Celina C. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha Provincia de Maputo, viúva e mãe de 5 filhos de 21 aos 36 anos somente dois vão a Escola. Fez 3ª classe não concluiu devido a gravidez precoce. Vive na casa propria com a sua família e responsabiliza se pelos seus bisnetos que vivem com ela em sua casa.


Após seu casamento obteve 5 filhos com seu esposo, mas este perde a vida e anos depos ela recebe uma indeminização proveniente do serviço do seu falecido esposo e então inicia o seu próprio negócio. E negociante a mais de 15 anos vende vestuarios e cobertores gastando uma média de 10.000.00mt em cada viagem, conta com ajuda sua filha que lhe ajuda nos negócios e tem de lucro 6.000.00mt que aplica nas dispesas da casa e poupa algum em sua conta bancaria.

Este é o quarto empréstimo de Celina na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar roupa diversa para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os anteriores no valor de (7.000.00, 15.000.00 e 15.000.00)mt foram usados para a mesma finalidade. 

Tem como objetivo para o futuro construir um salão de beleza e butique e deixar de vender somente por encomendas.
texts.en:
Celina was born in the Namaacha District, in the Maputo Province. She is a widow and mother of five children ranging in age from 21 to 36 years. Only two of them go to school. She completed 3rd grade but didn't finish school due to a teenage pregnancy. She lives in her own house with her family and supports her great grandchildren who live with her. During her marriage she had 5 children with her husband. He passed away and years later she received compensation from his job and started her own business. She has been in business for more than 15 years selling clothing and blankets. She spends around 10,000 meticais per trip and is helped by her daughter. She has an income of 6,000 meticais which is spent with household expenses. She saves some money in her bank account. This is Celina's fourth loan with Hluvuku and second with Kiva. It is for 20,000 and she intends to purchase assorted clothing to increase her inventory. The previous loans (for 7,000, 15,000 and 15,000 meticais) were used for the same goal. Her goal for the future is to build a beauty salon and a boutique and to stop only selling through pre-orders.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of assorted clothing

loans.name: Bolathan

texts.en:
Bolathan B., 38 years old, lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. His two children both attend a local school, while his wife works as a seamstress in her own workplace.

Bolathan has operated a transportation service in his town since 1991, delivering various products including stone, pebble and sand during the summer season; in the winter he usually transports coal, selling it in a local market. Bolathan owns two vehicles, a small car and a big truck, using his car as a taxi during the evening.

Bolathan, a very modest and polite person, says, "The transportation business is a difficult one to operate, especially during winter months." He is now requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan both to purchase four new wheels for the trailer he uses to haul materials and to use as working capital.

loans.use: To purchase four new wheels

loans.name: Isabel Antonio

texts.pt:
Isabel Antonio Sindique, nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha tem 31 anos de idade, solteira mãe de um bebe de apenas 1 ano de idade. Fez o ensino médio e depois o curso de professorado. Vive na casa propria com o seu filho e sustenta seus três sobrinhos que vivem com ela em sua casa.

Isabel apos concluir o curso de professorado opta em construir sua própria casa, seu pai que possuia uma grande porção de terra, faz a repartição para os filhos sendo ela uma das beneficiarias, fixa sua residência no mesmo quintal. E professsora ha mais de 8 anos trabalha das 12:15 as 17:40 auferindo mensalmente 5.900.00mt que aplica nas dispesas da casa e da obra, consegue poupar muito pouco deste valor porque possui uma empregada que aufere 1.000.00mt por mês que ajuda nos trabalhos de casa. 

Já teve empréstimos no BIM pagou com muito sucesso. Este é o primeiro na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, tijoleiras e outros) para dar continuidade com a obra da sua casa que iniciara com o empréstimo que obteve no BIM. 

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo para mobiliar a sua casa dando mais conforto a sua familia.
texts.en:
Isabel Antonio was born in the Namaacha District. She is 31 years old, single and the mother of a one year old baby. She finished high school and went on to conclude her teacher's training. She lives in her own home with her son and supports three nephews/nieces who live with her. After finishing her teacher's training she decided to build her house. Her father had a big lot of land and divided it between his children. She was one of the beneficiaries and built her home on that lot. She has been a teacher for more than 8 years. She works from 12:15pm to 5:40pm and makes 5,900 meticais per month which is spent with household expenses and construction. She only manages to save a little because she has a domestic helper who makes 1,000 meticais per month to help her around the house. She has had a loan with BIM (another bank) and was successful paying it back. This is her first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. It is for 15,000 meticais and she intends to buy construction materials (cement, sand, tiles and others) to continue the house construction she started with the loan from BIM. She is confident she will pay the loan ahead of schedule and request a new loan to furnish her house offering better living conditions to her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, tiles and others)

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Erdenetsetseg H., age 41, lives with her husband and two sons in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family have been living in their permanent home address since 2000. Her husband drives a car as a taxi to support his family. Her two sons attend a local high school.

Erdenetsetseg started her business in 2003, purchasing used raw materials at the wholesale price and reselling them retail. In the beginning, she purchased only vodka glass but since then her business has expanded and she has been collecting all kinds of used raw materials.

Erdenetsetseg increased her workplace by locating one container in a remote district and hired one worker in her new workplace. She also owns several livestock in the countryside. She is modest and hardworking person who says "I want to enlarge my business by opening a new workplace at home and to increase my business profits."

Erdenetsetseg is requesting a 3,150,000 MNT loan to expand her business by building new workshop at home.

loans.use: To build a new workshop at home

loans.name: Hivadat

texts.en:
Hivadat M. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and seven children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest two children are students while the other five children attend a local school. His wife works as a private businesswoman.

Hivadat operates an iron-crafting business in his town. He started his business in 1998 by producing only horseshoes but since then he expanded his product line to include a variety of chimneys and stovepipes. He has gained a many years of work experience as a blacksmith.

Hivadat's business earnings have enabled him to support his entire big family. He is a very modest and honest person. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more iron and steel in order to make his products.

loans.use: To purchase more iron and steel

loans.name: Akakpo Adjovi

texts.fr: D.  est mère de famille, elle a 3 enfants et vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de bè souza. elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des articles de mercerie. elle fait ce commerce depuis 2006 et s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. elle demande de WAGES un crédit pour augmenter son stock et gagner plus d'argent surtout en ce début de rentrée scolaire où la demande est très élevée
texts.en:
D. is the mother of three children. She lives with her family in the neighborhood of Bè Souza. She makes a living selling haberdashery items. She has been doing this since 2006, and she gets her supplies at the big market of Lomé. She is seeking a loan from WAGES to increase her stocks and boost her income, especially with the start of the school year where demand is very high.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various haberdashery items

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.en:
Elisabeth is 38 years old and is married with four children. She is well-known in the business of selling different styles of clothes and shoes. She has been in this business for about a year and her business hours are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Elisabeth needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. With this loan, she will expand her business through purchasing different styles of clothes and shoes to sell. With this business expansion, she will hopefully earn more profits which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business for better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase different styles of clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina Y. is a married woman who lives in Purok Batad, Barangay Gairan, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: dried fish vending, a general store and a fishing business. Her husband, Eufenio Y., who is 42 years old, works as a checker and as a Barangay (village) Councilor to earn his living. They have four children who are from 10 to 20 years old. Cristina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon four years ago because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, Cristina is borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use to purchase raw materials like dried fish so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children and to put up her own general store. Cristina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alozouhoin

texts.fr: A. est une femme de 44 ans très dynamique. elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes. elle a 6 ans d'ancienneté dans ce commerce. elle s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé où ce commerce est très développé. elle  a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé, elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante. elle sollicite un second crédit pour s'approvisionner avec des pagnes de diverses qualités et ainsi satisfaire la demande de ses clientes. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
A. is a 44-year old woman who is very dynamic. She has an income-generating activity selling "pagnes" (highly decorative West African fabric). She has six years' experience in this business. She gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé where this business is highly developed. She has already had one loan from WAGES, which she repaid in full. She carries out her business on a door-to-door basis. She is requesting a second loan in order to get new supplies of different quality "pagnes" in order to satisfy customer demand. She is married and mother to three children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Alexis

texts.en:
Alexis is 35 years old and is married with four children. He owns a piece of land where he grows tomatoes and he has been in this business for about five years. He starts working on his land early in the morning and finishes late in the evening hours.

Alexis needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase a machine to be used in fertilizing his tomatoes. With this machine, he hopes that his harvest will increase which, in turn, will increase his sales as well as his profits.

If successful, Alexis will be able to continue taking care of his family and, in addition to that, he will keep finding out how to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a machine to fertilize his tomatoes

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en: Zosima C. is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a tricycle operator business. She lives in Purok San Roque, Barangay Kawit, Medellin, Cebu. Zosima has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and tricycle businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,400. Zosima is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more products to sell and also to use as a partial payment for a tricycle. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganoon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Zosima aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell and to make a partial payment on a tricycle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ahmatillo

texts.en: U. Ahmatillo has a responsibility that makes him work hard for improvement. He is farmer. He grows wheat, onion, corn, pumpkins and other vegetables, work with which he is hopeful of making progress to provide what is necessary for his needy family. For that reason he wants to invest in his production, expand his crop fields and improve the quality of his products. Ahmatillo knows that if he takes care of his land and works diligently, he will reap excellent products that will have a better reception in the marketplace. The loan request he is making is to purchase seed and fertilizer necessary for his land. Please support this hardworking man so that his effort is worthwhile. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en: Nazira D. is a 33-year-old attentive mother of two girls. Her husband, Taalay, works in the police department. This couple lives in harmony and teaches their daughters to develop in balance. Nazira graduated from Trade College and worked as a cashier in a local supermarket. As it was hard to live on low wages, she decided to begin her own business. Using her initial capital of 9,000 KGS, she started to sell women’s clothes at the local market. Her start as an entrepreneur was successful due to her strong efforts. In 2009, Nazira obtained her first loan of 50,000 KGS from Bai Tushum and Partners, which was used as intended and repaid without any delays. As Nazira’s activity started successfully and her clientele has increased, she is applying for a loan of 60,000 KGS to broaden the range of goods in her shop. With the revenues, she plans to give a good education to her daughters. In the future, Nazira wants to enlarge her business by opening a second selling point. As for personal plans, she dreams of giving birth to one more child. About Bai-Tushum and Partners: Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Wendy

texts.en: Wendy G. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Palanas, Ginatilan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: fish vending, hog raising and farming. Her husband, Pepito G., who is 45 years old, works as a fisherman and carpenter to earn his living. They have five children who are from 10 to 25 years old. Wendy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, Wendy is borrowing PHP 16,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save for the future college education of her children. Wendy is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yawa Massa

texts.fr: yawa massa exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail des articles scolaires. elle fait ce commerce depuis plus de 4 ans, elle a été enseignante et donc elle connait les avantages de faire ce type de commerce. la rentrée des classes est proches et elle veut augmenter ses profits. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter divers articles scolaires. elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
Yawa Massa has an income-generating activity selling school materials on a retail basis. She has been carrying out this activity for more than four years. She has been a teacher and thus knows the advantages of this type of business. With the return to school approaching she wants to increase her profits and she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy various school materials. She is married and mother to two children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of school materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Patricia M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called In God We Trust.  She is 30 years old, married, and has two children between the ages of three and 12 years old. She is a sophomore college student.

For eight years, she has been selling used clothes in the Waterside Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. 

She describes herself as a very quiet woman whose dreams are to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Sherozjon

texts.en:
H. Sherozjon is 25 years old. He is married with two small children. His wife is a housekeeper and takes care of their children. Thus Sherozjon is the main bread-winner in the family. Sherozjon’s children are small now, but he is already working hard in order to ensure the best future for them. For more than 15 years Sherozjon has been baking the national bread “lepeshka”. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He gets up early and bakes "lepeshka" and other breads so that people can have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. He purchases all the ingredients such as flour, salt and yeast from the local market. Now Sherozjon is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni. The loan will be spent on purchasing flour and coal for baking “lepeshka”.  Sherozjon deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the country's already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchasing flour for baking national bread “lepeshka”

loans.name: Mighty Power Group

texts.en:
Akine S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Mighty Power. He is 35 years old, single, and has two children who are between the ages of two months to five years. Akine was only able to attend school to eleventh grade due to a lack of financial support. He describes himself as a faithful man.

For five years he has been selling milk, tea, sugar, powder, soap, hair grease and mosquito spray in the West Point Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 20,000 LRD portion of this 71,000 LRD group loan to buy more cartons of milk, tea, sugar, powder, soap, hair grease and mosquito spray. His dreams are to improve his business, educate his children and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Amondou B. is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of milk, tea, sugar, powder, soap, hair grease and mosquito spray

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu  le commerce de  pagnes, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005 et sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. actuellement son stock de marchandises a connu une baisse et elle souhaite se réapprovisionner en achetant 10 pagnes de qualité Hi-target,10 pagnes WAX et divers autres pagnes.
texts.en:
This woman makes a living selling pagnes (colorful African print cloth). She has been engaged in this activity since 2005 and has a diverse customer base. Her stocks are currently depleted, and she wishes to restock by buying ten Hi-Target grade pagnes, ten wax pagnes, and other varieties of this cloth.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pagnes

loans.name: Blessing Women Group

texts.en:
Comfort N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Blessing Women.  She is 42 years old, married, and has seven children between the ages of six and 18 years old. She was only able to attend school to eleventh grade due to financial difficulty.

For fifteen years, she has been selling lappas(a traditional dress for women) in various communities around Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of lappas (a traditional dress for women). She describes herself as a very hard-working woman whose dreams are to improve her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Beatrice is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of lappas (a traditional dress for women)

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda N., a happy mother of four children, is 42 years old and married. For 10 years she has been selling foodstuffs in her grocery store. Mavluda’s wish is to increase her business by offering a greater variety of foodstuffs to her customers who pass through this market. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are all the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts. With this opportunity and with the immense love Mavluda feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of $3000 USD in order to increase the range of her goods.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs in order to increase her range of goods for sale

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman is a young mother from Gaza city in Gaza Strip. Iman has two daughters and one son. Her husband Mahdi owns a bird store in Gaza and works there while Iman takes care of the house and kids.

Mahdi wants to purchase a large number of birds but he needs money to do so. Iman came to FATEN and received a $1000 loan to help her husband purchase the birds and improve his store. 

This loan will help the family sell more birds and increase their returns, which will improve their situation.  Iman's children are school students.

Mahdi appears in the picture here in front of his birds because Iman is from a conservative family and is not comfortable having her picture posted online.

loans.use: To purchase birds

loans.name: Bayi

texts.fr: bayi est une femme de 44 ans qui est très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, grâce à ce commerce elle subvient à ses charges et à ceux de son enfant. Elle s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays dans la ville d'anié. elle a une ancienneté de 6 ans dans ce commerce. elle a constaté une baisse de son stock de marchandises. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'une trentaine de sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Bayi is a very energetic 44 year-old woman. Her line of business is selling charcoal. Thanks to this business she supports herself and her child. She gets her stock in the interior of the country, in the town of Anié. She has six years of experience in this business and has noticed that her stock of merchandise is low. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy about thirty bags of charcoal and provide for the transport of the merchandise.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Fakhridin

texts.en:
Fakhridin S., a 42-year-old married father of three children, is a hardworking person who has been providing taxi services for the past 15 years. Lately, thanks to his taxi business, he has been able open his own grocery near his house. Most important to him is that his children in the future are able to complete university studies and become professionals.

Fakhridin wishes to keep his taxi business growing, and to do so he needs to have his working tools in good working order. He is requesting a loan to buy spare parts for his car and foodstuffs for his grocery to improve his business. Thanks to his entrprises Fakhridin has been able to stabilize his and his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing his car and foodstuffs for his grocery store

loans.name: Put Together Group

texts.en:
Ruth D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Put Together. She is 48 years old and is widowed with four children between the ages of 21 and 30 years. She was only able to attend school through fifth grade due to financial difficulties.

For twenty years, Ruth has been selling dried fish in the "12th Street community" market in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 38,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cartons of fish to sell.

Ruth describes herself as a God-fearing woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish to sell

loans.name: Melikuzi

texts.en: B. Melikuzi is 59 years old and, together with his wife, he’s raised seven children. Melikuzi has been running a drugstore for five years already. He sells only certified medicines. Hard work and a clear purpose - to provide for his family - have made his business grow. Melikuzi has been a client of IMON for almost three years. Now, he requests 5,000 Somoni to increase his assortment of medicines. Being a very accurate person by his nature, he is sure and would like to assure the lenders that he is able to pay the loan on time without any problems. This business is the only source of income for Melikuzi’s family, so he wants to run it well. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To increase his assortment of medicines

loans.name: Know Yourself Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Know Yourself. She is 50 years old and is married with four children between the ages of 20 and 31 years. She was only able to attend school through fifth grade due to financial difficulties.

For fifteen years, Jacqueline has been selling onions, red oil, pepper, salt, soap and seasoning in G. Town community outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 26,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 54,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more onions, red oil, pepper, salt, soap and seasoning.

Jacqueline describes herself as a determined woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more onions, red oil, pepper, salt, soap and seasoning to sell

loans.name: Nigina

texts.en: Nigina is married and has one child. She runs a small business selling kid’s clothing in the central market of Kumsangir, Tajikistan. She believes that one of the biggest advantages of her work is a flexible schedule that gives her the opportunity to take good care of her family. Nigina has been in business for three years and her attentiveness and creativity have helped her develop a good understanding of what her clients need and want. They always feel complimented when she goes out of her way to help them with their selections. This has naturally boosted her sales and led to growth in her business. Nigina is requesting a loan of 4,000 Somoni to enable her to significantly expand her business by purchasing a new vending facility. She is hoping to reinvest the generated income in further expansion of her business. She believes that consistent growth will help her provide a stable source of income and will continue to secure her family’s well-being. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchasing a new vending facility

loans.name: Homegan Kossi

texts.fr: A. est un tenancier de bar qu'il a appelé "ETS FIRST CLASS". les weekends et les vendredis soirs, son bar est très animé. il dispose de Trois employés et s'approvisionne en boissons auprès de la Brasserie de Lomé. son stock de boissons est fini, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit qui est son deuxième pour acheter 35 casiers de boissons sucrerie et bières et divers pour alimenter son bar. IL est célibataire.
texts.en:
Mr. A. is the manager of a bar he calls “ETS FIRST CLASS.” His bar is very lively on Friday nights and on weekends. He has three employees and gets his stock of drinks from the Lomé Brasserie. As his stock of drinks is depleted, he is requesting a second loan from WAGES to buy 35 cases of various sweetened drinks and beers to supply his bar. He is a bachelor.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cases of drinks

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina B., age 52, works hard to cover her daily expenses. For the past ten years she has owned and run her own direct-selling clothes and shoes business. She often has trouble with customers who purchase goods on credit, not paying her for the orders they made, but she has still managed to generate a steady income stream from her business.

Carolina has requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to help her purchase additional inventory, including new clothes, shoes, etc. She hopes that the loan will enable her to continue to meet customer demands and hopefully attract additional business.

Carolina has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2005, and has consistently attended its weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that someday she will have her own house and be able to purchase a motorcycle tricycle so that her children can use it to generate additional income.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more onions, red oil, pepper, salt, soap, seasoning and tomatoes

loans.name: Zam

texts.en:
Zam N. lives in the Lugala, Kosovo, neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and medication.

Zam has a business of selling bananas. She has been in this business for over ten years and works seven days a week. She sells on retail basis at the market.

Zam has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income through tailoring.

The main business challenges for Zam include seasonality and thieves. Her goal and aspiration for her business is to start going directly to villages for bananas. She decided to join MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas to sell

loans.name: Royal Family Group

texts.en:
Marol Y., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Royal Family. She is 22 years old, is single, and has three children between the ages of nine months and 8 years. She is a college freshman.

For three years, Marol has been selling sugar, red oil, and rice in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 26,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 62,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more sugar, red oil, and rice to sell.

Marol describes herself as a trustworthy woman whose dream is to improve her business, build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, red oil, and rice to sell

loans.name: God Help Us Group

texts.en:
Satta T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Help Us. She is 55 years old and is married with five children who are between the ages of 10 and 35 years. She was not able to attend school herself due to financial constraints.

For twenty years, Satta has been selling bananas, tomatoes and oranges in Joe Bar’s Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bananas, tomatoes and oranges to sell.

Satta describes herself as an honest and trustworthy woman whose dream is to improve her business, build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, tomatoes and oranges to sell

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr: L. est un homme marié et père d'un enfant, il est âgé de 27 ans, en 2006 il a ouvert une boutique de vente de pièces détachées qu'il a appelé " ETS PETIT PRIX".il s'approvisionne au marché local du port de lomé où ce type d'activité est très dense. il a constaté une baisse de son stock raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de diverses pièces détachées de véhicule.
texts.en:
Mr. L. is married and has one child. He is 27 years old. In 2006, he opened a spare parts store which he has named “Etc low price.” He stocks up in the local market at the port of Lomé where this type of business is very common. At present his stock is low, which is why he is seeking a loan from WAGES to purchase various automotive spare parts.
